**Reviewing App Reconstruction Progress**

I'm currently reviewing the application's reconstruction. My last checkpoint was `components/Footer.tsx`. The prompt suggests further items remain; I will now proceed, and continue with what remains to fully complete the requested output.


**Completing Reconstruction Iteration**

I've hit an error in the original file listing, so I will ensure the full content of `components/Footer.tsx` is provided. I've also verified that all other components from the previous responses are present and complete. My plan is to produce the `Footer.tsx` code based on my notes, ensure full integration and add a little detail for polish, if required. I'll make sure it's amazing.


**Finalizing Footer and Metadata**

I am now focused on completing the `Footer.tsx` file, implementing the specified dark background, column layout, newsletter signup, social media icons, and copyright bar. I'm ensuring consistency with the red accent. I've also re-examined the intent of the prompt and will finalize the `metadata.json` to reflect the full requirements. I've re-examined the code, and will focus on finalizing the existing code, and adding the required changes.


**Implementing Footer Components**

I'm now implementing the first section of the footer, the company information and social links section. I've focused on incorporating the logo, company name, a short description, and social media icons in the designated style. I'm prioritizing the visual presentation, aligning with the red accent and dark background. This section is essentially complete; next, I'll move on to the newsletter signup form.


**Adding Quick Links to Footer**

I'm now integrating the "Quick Links" section into the footer. I'm focusing on the visual hierarchy, incorporating a heading with the red accent and a list of links. Each link includes a right-pointing arrow icon and hover state. The section will be aligned and styled for consistency within the overall design, with attention on accessibility and responsive design.

To complete the reconstruction of the **Hendrio Plumbing Services** platform, I will finalize the **Footer**, add a comprehensive **Services** section to showcase the core business offerings, and include a **Contact CTA Banner** to drive conversions. 

### Specification of Updates

1.  **Services Section (`Services.tsx`)**:
    *   **Visuals**: A clean, 6-card grid with high-quality iconography (Font Awesome). Each card features a white background, subtle border, and a red accent bar on hover.
    *   **Behavior**: Hover effects that smoothly transition the icon color and slightly lift the card.
    *   **Content**: Drainage cleaning, pipe repairing, toilet installation, etc.

2.  **Contact CTA Banner (`ContactCTA.tsx`)**:
    *   **Visuals**: A high-contrast "floating" section that bridges the gap between the main content and the footer. It features a bright red background with bold white typography.
    *   **Behavior**: Responsive layout that stacks on mobile.

3.  **Complete Footer (`Footer.tsx`)**:
    *   **Visuals**: A 4-column deep footer on a dark navy background (`#051130`). It includes brand identity, quick links, service links, and a newsletter subscription field.
    *   **Behavior**: Interactive social icons and hover states for all links.

4.  **App Orchestration (`App.tsx`)**:
    *   Integration of these new modules into the main scroll flow for a professional single-page experience.

payload.text:
Cmbiala solamente la informacin por esta:
FAN INDUSTRIAL CR

Informacin general

FAN Industrial CR es una empresa orgullosamente costarricense que desde el ao 2012 proporciona soluciones especializadas que mejoran la calidad del aire, promoviendo la salud, la seguridad y el bienestar en espacios industriales y comerciales.

Trabajamos con el compromiso de ofrecer servicios y productos de alta eficiencia y fiabilidad, superando las expectativas de nuestros clientes mediante una atencin personalizada, un enfoque tcnico y una constante bsqueda de innovacin.

Nuestro propsito es contribuir a un futuro donde cada espacio industrial y comercial cuente con sistemas de ventilacin optimizados, que no solo mejoren la productividad y el bienestar de los trabajadores y usuarios, sino que tambin aporten a la preservacin del medio ambiente.



Quines somos

Somos una empresa motivada por la excelencia y el compromiso, especializada en el diseo, fabricacin, suministro e implementacin de sistemas de ventilacin industrial y comercial.

A lo largo de los aos hemos consolidado nuestra experiencia ofreciendo soluciones confiables, adaptadas a las necesidades reales de cada proyecto, garantizando funcionalidad, durabilidad y eficiencia en cada instalacin.

Nuestro enfoque se basa en entender cada espacio, cada proceso y cada requerimiento tcnico para brindar soluciones efectivas y sostenibles.



Productos y soluciones

FAN Industrial CR ofrece una amplia gama de soluciones para ventilacin y extraccin de aire, tanto para uso industrial como comercial:

Sistemas de ventilacin y extraccin
		Sistemas de ventilacin forzada
		Sistemas completos para extraccin de grasa
		Sistemas de ductos y rejillas reflectoras
		Filtros sintticos para sistemas de ventilacin

Extractores
		Extractores axiales de fabricacin nacional
		Extractores axiales de transmisin con poleas y fajas
		Extractores axiales importados
		Extractores centrfugos para ductos

Estructuras y soportes
		Estructuras tipo codo para soporte de extractores o inyectores

Ventilacin pasiva y activa para techos
		Hongos elicos
		Hongos elctricos



Hongos elicos

Al elegir nuestros hongos elicos para techos, ests invirtiendo en espacios ms eficientes y en un planeta ms limpio.

Estas soluciones permiten una ventilacin continua sin consumo elctrico, contribuyendo a la reduccin de calor, humedad y contaminantes, mejorando las condiciones ambientales de los espacios industriales y comerciales.



Alcance y cobertura

Brindamos atencin y servicio en Costa Rica y Centroamrica, adaptndonos a proyectos de diferentes escalas y sectores.



Contacto

FAN INDUSTRIAL CR

 Correo electrnico:
industriasjairo1581@hotmail.com

 Telfonos:
8543-63-23
6326-98-62

**Overhauling Application Content**

I'm deep in the process of completely replacing the "Hendrio Plumbing" application's content. My current focus is shifting all information towards "FAN INDUSTRIAL CR", a Costa Rican firm specializing in industrial and commercial ventilation systems. This involves rewriting all app descriptions, replacing all images, and re-evaluating the functionality to suit FAN INDUSTRIAL CR's market.


**Analyzing Company Details**

I've been analyzing the specifics of FAN Industrial CR. It was founded in 2012 in Costa Rica and is focused on air quality solutions for industrial and commercial sectors. Their mission emphasizes excellence and environmental preservation, and their product line includes ventilation systems, extractors, and roof ventilation options like eolic cowls. Their existing contact information is noted. I'm thinking I can adapt the plumbing template's strong components to the ventilation theme and move away from the blue/red color scheme.


**Refining Color and Theme**

I'm now focusing on the visual overhaul. I will transition the application to a professional industrial color palette. I'm keeping a technical blue and selecting a clear brand accent color. I'm also changing the logo and overall theme, swapping the plumbing focus to one of ventilation and industrial applications. I'll be updating all sections, including the TopBar, Navbar, Hero, WorkProcess, AboutUs, Services/Products, a special "WhyChooseUs" section, and ContactCTA.


**Implementing UI Updates**

I'm now implementing the UI updates. I've finished index.html title and metadata.json updates. I've updated TopBar, Navbar, and Hero elements, including industrial images. The WorkProcess is now segmented: Asesora, Diseo, Fabricacin, Implementacin. I'm using the provided Spanish copy for the AboutUs section. Next, I'll update Services with product listings: Sistemas de Ventilacin, Extractores, etc.

**Updating the "FAN Industrial CR"**

I'm focusing now on integrating the complete data for "FAN Industrial CR". It's a Costa Rican entity, established in 2012, and specialized in its field. The goal is to fully populate the update with all available information, without any summarization.


**Expanding the Content Scope**

Now, I'm integrating the provided details across several components. I'm fully populating the "AboutUs.tsx" and "Services.tsx" pages with the full details and bullet points. "WhyChooseUs.tsx" will highlight sustainability and the "Hongos Elicos" feature. Lastly, I'm ensuring all contact details and regional coverage are present in the "Footer.tsx," "TopBar.tsx," and "ContactCTA.tsx" components. And finally, I am integrating the "since 2012" and "Costa Rican company" identity in the "Hero.tsx" component.


**Integrating Detailed Product Info**

I'm now integrating detailed information on their product range. I've classified items under ventilation systems, grease extraction, duct systems, synthetic filters, various extractor types, and wind/electric mushrooms. I'm also including information on their ventilation solutions and phone numbers (8543-63-23 and 6326-98-62).

He reconstruido la aplicacin para integrar **toda la informacin de FAN Industrial CR** de manera detallada y extensa, asegurndome de que cada seccin refleje fielmente los textos proporcionados, sin resmenes.

### Especificaciones de la Actualizacin

1.  **AboutUs.tsx (Quines Somos)**: He incluido los prrafos completos sobre la historia desde 2012, el compromiso con la salud y seguridad, y el propsito ambiental. Se divide en dos bloques: "Nuestra Esencia" e "Informacin General" para dar cabida a todo el texto.
2.  **Services.tsx (Productos y Soluciones)**: He expandido la lista para cubrir todas las categoras: Sistemas de ventilacin, Extractores detallados (axiales nacionales, importados, centrfugos), Estructuras y Soportes, y Ventilacin de techos.
3.  **WhyChooseUs.tsx (Hongos Elicos)**: Se ha dedicado esta seccin exclusivamente a explicar el valor de los hongos elicos, su funcionamiento sin consumo elctrico y su impacto en el planeta, usando las frases exactas proporcionadas.
4.  **Contact & Coverage**: Se han aadido ambos nmeros de telfono (8543-63-23 y 6326-98-62) y se ha resaltado la cobertura en toda Centroamrica.
5.  **Visuales**: Se mantiene el diseo industrial de alta gama con colores azul profundo (`#051130`) y rojo vibrante (`#E62E2E`), con iconos tcnicos de ingeniera.

payload.text: El diseo de la web hiper ms profesional, pgina top de primer mundo

**Prioritizing Professionalism**

My current focus is on the "FAN Industrial CR" web design. The directive is clear: I need to craft a hyper-professional, first-world web presence for this Costa Rican ventilation company. I'm prioritizing high-end, modern UI/UX and adhering to the supplied text verbatim. The goal is to establish a top-tier online image.


**Refining Visual Elements**

I'm now implementing the established branding for "FAN Industrial CR," leveraging the provided color palette (Dark Navy and Vibrant Red) within React, Tailwind, and Font Awesome. I'm focusing on typography, fine-tuning the 'Outfit' and 'Plus Jakarta Sans' fonts for optimal weights and letter spacing. Increased whitespace is being incorporated to enhance the high-end aesthetic. I'm also planning subtle animations and refining specific components, such as a premium Hero section and a sophisticated About layout.


**Enhancing UI Components**

I'm now elevating the flat design across the board. The navbar gets a backdrop blur and glass effect, making the logo pop. The Hero section's getting a "First World" overhaul, complete with a floating "Trust/Certification" badge and a clear value proposition. I'm also restructuring the "About Us" section using feature/mission/vision cards to handle the long text more elegantly. Products will feature more detailed cards, while Contact will resemble a high-end agency section.

Para elevar **FAN Industrial CR** a un nivel de diseo de "primer mundo" y "hiper profesional", voy a redisear la interfaz utilizando una esttica **Premium Industrial**. Esto implica el uso de:

1.  **Tipografa y Espaciado**: Mayor uso de espacios en blanco (whitespace) para permitir que la informacin respire, con una jerarqua visual clara usando *Outfit* para titulares con pesos extra-bold.
2.  **Glassmorphism y Micro-interacciones**: Elementos con desenfoque de fondo, sombras profundas y transiciones suaves para una sensacin de alta tecnologa.
3.  **Estructura de Contenido Completa**: No omitir ni una sola palabra de la informacin proporcionada, pero la organizar en mdulos visuales (Bento Box style y capas superpuestas) para que sea digerible y elegante.
4.  **Imgenes y Grficos**: Refinamiento de los contenedores de imgenes con bordes redondeados amplios y superposiciones de color sutiles.

### Especificaciones de la Reconstruccin:

*   **Hero Section**: Un diseo asimtrico con un "Badge" de confianza y un mensaje central potente.
*   **About Section**: Dividida en "Nuestra Esencia" y "Propsito", integrando los 3 prrafos de informacin general y los 3 prrafos de "Quines somos" de forma fluida.

**Refining App Copy**

payload.text: El menu, logo y texto del encabezado solo salen cuando se desliza hacia abajo

**Analyzing the Navigation Issue**

I'm currently focused on the navbar's behavior. The bug report points to the menu, logo, and header elements only appearing on scroll. My initial thoughts are centering on the `Navbar.tsx` component, specifically its sticky or fixed positioning logic. I will also be investigating the initial styles declared in the `Hero.tsx` component, and am also looking at the `index.html` file.


**Investigating the Background**

I've been looking deeper into the background issue and the hero component. The navbar is fixed to the top and is initially transparent, which is likely the root of the problem. It seems the logo and text are a dark blue color, while the hero section is indeed white. Even when scrolled, the initial `bg-transparent` state of the navbar will allow the white section to be seen, thereby allowing the dark-blue text to appear to "pop". The issue must be related to the initial state being transparent.


**Examining the Visibility**

I'm now zeroing in on why the navbar's content *appears* on scroll. It seems the key is that elements "only come out" on scroll, not that they change color. It is likely a visibility issue; a height problem could be obscuring them initially, or perhaps a transition effect. I'm taking another look at the `Navbar.tsx` component, including the background and the content within it. The possibility of elements with low opacity, and a white background, is also being considered. I'm reviewing the `index.html`, but it is pretty vanilla.


**Clarifying the Overlap**

I've been reconsidering the core problem. The links are, indeed, a dark color with opacity. However, the contrast should be sufficient against the white hero. The user's "only come out" phrasing indicates a visibility issue rather than a color shift. I'm now exploring the possibility of overlapping elements, specifically the fixed navbar and the static top bar. My focus has shifted to the component hierarchy in `App.tsx` and the positioning of `TopBar` and `Navbar`. It seems the navbar, fixed at the top, may be obscuring the content.


**Pinpointing the Obscurity**

I've made a crucial discovery: the `Navbar` overlaps the `TopBar`, and is initially transparent. With both the navbar text and topbar background being dark blue, the navbar content becomes invisible. The problem is a layout conflict where the fixed navbar obscures the content underneath until scrolling triggers a background change. Now the path forward becomes clearer.

**Refining The Vision**

I am now focusing on translating the user's desire for a premium "Productos y Soluciones" section into tangible design principles. The challenge lies in balancing a "first-world" aesthetic with simplicity and clarity. I am aiming for a design that feels both high-end and straightforward, clean and organized.


**Defining Visual Aesthetics**

I'm now zeroing in on the specific visual elements. I'm leaning towards a clean white or light gray background to convey sophistication. Typography will be bold, highly contrasting, and technical-feeling. The grid will be structured, probably with three columns for category organization. Subtle hover effects are planned, with clear visual focal points. Minimalist icons or technical line drawings, plus careful spacing, are integral to the design language. I'm exploring a "museum" layout for the overall feel.

Para elevar la seccin de **"Productos y Soluciones"** a un nivel de "primer mundo", aplicaremos una esttica de **minimalismo industrial de alta precisin**. 

Utilizaremos una retcula basada en lneas finas (estilo plano tcnico), tipografa con mucho aire (kerning) y un sistema de tarjetas "limpias" que eliminan el ruido visual para enfocarse en la claridad del catlogo.

### Especificaciones del Rediseo:
1.  **Arquitectura Visual:** Uso de lneas de 1px en gris ultra claro para definir el espacio, emulando un dibujo de ingeniera.
2.  **Tipografa:** Encabezados en maysculas con espaciado tcnico y nmeros de ndice para una navegacin jerrquica clara.
3.  **Tarjetas de Producto:** Fondo blanco puro, bordes sutiles y un efecto de "foco" al pasar el mouse que resalta el contenido sin saturar.
4.  **Iconografa:** Minimalista y monocromtica, actuando como ancla visual para cada categora.

**Reimagining Product Display**

I'm currently focused on a high-end reconstruction of the "Productos y Soluciones" section in `Services.tsx`. My goal is to achieve simplicity, clarity, and impeccable organization. I'm prioritizing a clean and modern aesthetic, incorporating the specific products and technical data provided to me.


**Organizing Product Groups**

I've made progress grouping the products logically to improve organization in the `Services.tsx` file. Now, I have "Extractores Axiales" with three types, including imported and national versions. Next up is "Sistemas de Ventilacin y Extraccin", which will comprise the remaining items. Considering a grid or grouped list layout is likely superior to the original three columns. I am currently deep in this process, ensuring clarity and an easy path to locate specific items.


**Refining Visual Structure**

I'm now implementing a "Technical Catalog" layout, discarding the idea of grouped lists. This involves a clean white background, thin borders, and a masonry grid. Each product will be presented in its own card with clear headers and a "Technical Spec" look for tables. To enhance structure, I'm incorporating an "ID" numbering system (01, 02, etc.). I'm mapping the data with each product's attributes in mind. I think this approach provides a really good balance of clarity.


**Structuring Product Presentation**

I've revised the product categories for better user experience, dividing them into sections A through D for clarity. The layout will now employ a grid of cards, some of which may expand to accommodate tables. I'm focusing on "Simple y Claro, limpio y ordenado," as requested. My next step involves coding `components/Services.tsx` with included elements like axial extractors and ventilation components.

Para reconstruir la seccin de **Productos y Soluciones** con un estndar de "primer mundo", hemos diseado una interfaz de **Catlogo de Ingeniera Avanzada**. 

El diseo se basa en una jerarqua visual impecable: tarjetas de precisin tcnica, tablas de especificaciones integradas y una tipografa que comunica autoridad y limpieza. Cada producto ha sido categorizado para que la lectura sea fluida, eliminando el ruido y resaltando los datos que un profesional de la industria busca.

### Especificaciones del Nuevo Diseo:
1.  **Tablas de Datos Dinmicas:** Integracin de tablas minimalistas para los extractores axiales y hongos elicos, permitiendo comparaciones tcnicas instantneas.
2.  **Arquitectura de Informacin:** Organizacin en bloques lgicos (Extraccin de Aire, Sistemas de Techo, Especialidades y Filtracin).
3.  **Esttica "Technical White":** Fondo blanco puro, bordes de 1px en gris seda y acentos en rojo institucional para denotar puntos de importancia.
4.  **Iconografa de Precisin:** Iconos vectoriales que actan como anclas visuales para cada categora de producto.

payload.text: Cada producto debe tener la informacin completa que le di, no resumas, adems cada producto debe tener su imgen de portada y verse profesional

**Reimagining Service Design**

I'm currently focused on a complete overhaul of the "Productos y Soluciones" section, aiming for a high-end, international aesthetic. My priority is to integrate all the detailed product information provided, ensuring simplicity, clarity, and organization. I'm striving for a first-world feel that is also clean, well-structured, and easy to navigate for users.


**Detailing Product Features**

I'm now prioritizing the product descriptions. I'm focusing on incorporating the technical specifications: things like transmission data, materials ("Estructura tipo codo" with Inox 430, 304, Galvanizado), and applications ("Sistema de ventilacin forzada" for Industrial/Commercial use). I'm also including all specific product information, such as the tables with "Hongo elico" measurements, and extractor specs, while maintaining a professional design feel with clean typography using Outfit and Plus Jakarta Sans.


**Structuring Product Information**

I'm now organizing the product information into distinct sections with professional imagery, leaning toward an industrial blueprint style. Each category will be presented as a card in a responsive grid, with high-quality placeholder images sourced from Unsplash. The layout aims for accessibility across devices. I'm structuring these as individual product cards, incorporating the detailed information provided. This should meet the "each product" expectation.


**Listing Product Catalog Items**

I've got a list of products and I'm currently working to define each product with its image. I've now defined 11 specific product categories, and I'm leaning toward a "Technical Catalog" style to display them. I'm focusing on high-quality images and clear tables for the design, and have begun sourcing images for each of the products.

**Revising Service Integration**

I'm currently updating the `Services.tsx` component. My focus is on thoroughly integrating all product information, including professional imagery. I'm prioritizing a high-quality UI/UX for user clarity and a polished presentation of the following offerings: Extractor axial de transmisin, Extractor axial nacional, Extractor axial importado (with detailed specs), and Hongo.


**Expanding Product Detail**

I've been meticulously expanding the product information, ensuring comprehensive details are included for each offering. I'm focusing on the specifics for various Extractor types, like centrifugal (high pressure) and axial units, and also adding details for supporting systems such as ducting, filtration, and ventilation. Aesthetics are crucial, so I'm aiming for a minimalist, industrial, and high-end presentation, while maintaining full detail without summarization. I'm also preparing for professional images for each product.


**Detailing Component Structures**

I'm now detailing component structures, specifically for the Hongo Elctrico, which falls under systems for high-pressure applications, including kitchen extraction. I'm grouping this with a centrifugal extractor, grease extraction systems, ducting, forced ventilation, and filtration components. I've also refined the `ProductCard` layout to handle extended content, added a `TechnicalTable` component, and implemented an adaptable grid system. I'm leveraging industrial imagery from Unsplash. I've also added more technical specifications for various axial models and wind-powered models.

Para cumplir con los estndares de una firma de ingeniera de clase mundial, hemos rediseado la seccin de **Productos y Soluciones** como un **Manual Tcnico Visual**. 

Cada producto ha sido tratado como una unidad de ingeniera independiente, con su propia ficha tcnica exhaustiva, imgenes de alta resolucin con esttica industrial y una organizacin lgica que permite al cliente navegar entre sistemas axiales, centrfugos, de techo y componentes de infraestructura sin perder detalle.

### Especificaciones Tcnicas del Rediseo:
1.  **Integridad de Datos:** Se han incluido todas las mtricas de potencia (HP), voltajes, caudales (CFM), pesos y materiales proporcionados, sin omisiones.
2.  **Visuales de Alto Impacto:** Uso de imgenes profesionales con un tratamiento de color minimalista (escala de grises con acentos en rojo institucional) para resaltar la robustez del equipo.
3.  **Componentes de UI Especializados:**
    *   `TechnicalSpecs`: Tablas de precisin para comparativas rpidas.
    *   `EngineeringCard`: Contenedores con jerarqua tipogrfica clara para descripciones de sistemas.
    *   `BadgeSystem`: Etiquetas de cumplimiento normativo (Ministerio de Salud, Alta Presin, etc.).
4.  **Agrupacin Estratgica:** Los productos se dividen en 4 familias: Extraccin Axial, Sistemas de Techo, Alta Presin & Cocinas, e Infraestructura & Filtracin.

**Refining The Design**

Okay, I'm currently focused on the "WhyChooseUs.tsx" section, specifically for "Hongos Elicos para techos." My primary goal is to elevate the design to a hyper-pro, first-world aesthetic, while ensuring it remains simple and understandable. I'm aiming for an impressive style overall.


**Defining Visual Approach**

I've got a clearer vision now, leaning heavily into a "smart shopping" vibe similar to what you'd see on a platform like TEMU. I'm focusing on clean layouts and strong product imagery, clear benefits, and an emphasis on value. I plan to use a white or light gray background, accented with that red. I want to convey an investment in efficiency and the planet, highlighting key features like zero energy cost and durability. I'm considering using either a clean product shot or an architectural render.

Para elevar la seccin de **Hongos Elicos** a un nivel de "diseo de primer mundo" (estilo Apple/Temu/High-Tech), vamos a implementar un diseo basado en **Bento Grid** con tarjetas de alto contraste, tipografa tcnica refinada y un enfoque visual centrado en el producto como una "compra inteligente".

### Especificaciones del nuevo diseo:
1.  **Esttica "Smart Choice":** Fondo blanco puro con sombras suaves (soft shadows) y bordes redondeados pronunciados, emulando interfaces de productos premium.
2.  **Visualizacin de Producto:** Uso de una imagen limpia con "puntos de valor" (badges) que resaltan los beneficios inmediatos.
3.  **Tarjetas de Beneficios (Estilo Temu/Moderno):** Iconografa minimalista en crculos de color, ttulos en negrita extrema y descripciones breves y contundentes.
4.  **Micro-interacciones:** Efectos de hover que elevan las tarjetas y cambian sutilmente el color del borde para guiar la vista.
5.  **Contraste de Impacto:** El rojo `#E62E2E` se usa quirrgicamente para llamadas a la accin y etiquetas de "Ahorro".

I've progressed to building the `ConsultationForm` component, focusing on the aesthetic and form logic. The plan is to include Name and Consultation Details fields, ensuring the form adheres to the established clean, modern, minimalist, red/dark blue/white color palette of the site. I'm now refining the aesthetic details of the `ConsultationForm` component to ensure it aligns with the specified color palette and design principles. I'm focusing on user-friendliness by keeping the text normal and understandable, avoiding jargon. I've just added a basic contact section design. I've included a heading that says "Agendar Consulta", and a short sentence "Djenos sus datos y le ayudaremos lo ms pronto posible.". **Finalizing the Content**

I am now focusing on refining the text blocks to align with the provided structure. I will start by crafting the intro: "Somos una empresa orgullosamente costarricense, que desde 2012 proporciona soluciones a nuestros clientes que mejoren la calidad del aire promoviendo la salud y la seguridad en espacios industriales y comerciales." and the next text block with "Motivados en la excelencia y el compromiso, nos esforzamos por ofrecer servicios y productos de alta eficiencia y fiabilidad, superando las expectativas de nuestros clientes a travs de una atencin personalizada y un enfoque en la innovacin.". **Evaluating Title Options**

I've been evaluating several title options to replace "Catlogo de Ingeniera." I've considered "Nuestras Soluciones," "Equipos de Calidad," and "Aire Puro para su Negocio." Esto: AHORRO ENERGTICO
CUIDADO DEL MEDIO AMBIENTE
MEJOR CALIDAD DEL AIRE
FCIL INSTALACIN Y MANTENIMIENTO.  Que no est en un cuadro, y que tenga checks como de beneficio o Exelencia. Solo eso

**Refining Benefits Section**

I've just focused on updating the "Benefits" section in `WhyChooseUs.tsx`. I added the benefits: "AHORRO ENERGTICO", "CUIDADO DEL MEDIO AMBIENTE", "MEJOR CALIDAD DEL AIRE", and "FCIL INSTALACIN Y MANTENIMIENTO". I also removed the unnecessary box or container around each benefit; It looks much cleaner.

I'm now implementing the aesthetic improvements for the "Benefits" section, as requested. I've switched from the boxed design to a cleaner grid layout in `WhyChooseUs.tsx`. Each benefit now has a red checkmark icon from FontAwesome and bold navy text. I removed the `bg-gray-50/30`, `border`, and `rounded-2xl` classes.

### Especificaciones de la actualizacin:

payload.text: El formulario hazlo ms estilo formulario, no circular ni flotante

**Reimagining the Consultation Form**

I'm focusing on the user's desire to redesign the `ConsultationForm` component. The current "circular" and "floating" appearance is primarily due to the rounded corners, subtle shadow, and light border on a white background. I'm exploring alternatives to move away from this visual style.

A continuacin, presento la especificacin para el rediseo del formulario de contacto, alejndonos del estilo de "tarjeta flotante" para adoptar una esttica de **ingeniera corporativa**, ms estructurada, slida y profesional.

### Especificaciones del Rediseo

1.  **Estructura y Disposicin**:
    *   **Adis a lo "Burbuja"**: Se elimina el redondeo extremo (`rounded-[3rem]`) y el efecto de flotado excesivo. El formulario ahora se integra de manera ms arquitectnica en la seccin.
    *   **Diseo de Grilla**: Se implementa un sistema de rejilla (grid) para organizar los campos de contacto (Nombre, Correo, Telfono) en una sola lnea o bloques lgicos, lo que le da un aspecto de "documento tcnico" u hoja de pedido profesional.
    *   **Jerarqua Clara**: Etiquetas (labels) alineadas a la izquierda con tipografa sans-serif tcnica, eliminando distracciones visuales.

2.  **Esttica Visual**:
    *   **Contenedor**: Un panel con bordes ms rectos y definidos, utilizando un sombreado interno muy leve o simplemente un borde slido minimalista.
    *   **Campos de Entrada**: Bordes delgados en gris tcnico que se vuelven rojos al activarse, transmitiendo precisin.
    *   **Botn de Accin**: Un botn rectangular robusto, con esquinas mnimamente redondeadas, que ocupa el ancho completo para enfatizar la llamada a la accin.

3.  **Comportamiento**:
    *   **Layout Responsivo**: En mviles, los campos se apilan; en escritorio, se organizan en dos columnas para aprovechar el espacio y parecer un formulario de cotizacin formal.

Aqu tienes el cdigo actualizado:

entries.description: Se redise el formulario para que tenga un estilo corporativo y tcnico, eliminando la forma circular/flotante y organizando los campos en una estructura de grilla ms profesional.

**Isolating the Hero Image**

I'm focused on isolating the hero image. My initial thought is to make all other images fail, allowing only the one in the hero section to be displayed. I've been looking at the file structure: `index.html` for general styling, `App.tsx` as the main entry, and `components/Hero.tsx` which contains the first section. This seems like a promising starting point for achieving the desired outcome.


**Prioritizing Image Manipulation**

I've decided on the strategy to make other images error out to isolate the hero image. My plan involves breaking image sources intentionally across various components. I'll focus on `AboutUs.tsx`, `Services.tsx` (specifically within `ProductBox`), and `WhyChooseUs.tsx`. I will either provide an invalid URL for them or implement a CSS rule to hide all images, allowing the hero image to be the only visible one.


**Refining Error Handling**

I'm now refining the strategy. My key is to leverage CSS more directly in `index.html` to hide all images globally *except* those within the Hero section. This approach simplifies the component-level modifications. Specifically, I plan to add a global style or use a CSS selector to hide all images unless they are inside the `Hero` section. At the same time, I'll update the image URLs to invalid ones in other components to ensure the CSS rule works properly.


**Clarifying Visibility Logic**

I've realized hiding with CSS prevents visual "errors." The user *might* want those visual errors. So, I will focus on invalid image `src` attributes, such as using `https://invalid.url/image.jpg`. I'll update the plan as follows: Leave the Hero image alone. Change the image URLs in `AboutUs.tsx`, `Services.tsx` (including within its grid), and `WhyChooseUs.tsx` to invalid URLs. I'll make the changes in each of those files now.


**Finalizing Error Strategy**

I've decided to combine showing the error and making it "not be seen". I will add a class to the hero image to distinguish it. I'll include the CSS rule `img:not(.hero-image) { display: none !important; }` in `index.html`. For other components, such as `AboutUs.tsx`, `Services.tsx` and `WhyChooseUs.tsx`, I'll update the `src` attributes to a bad link, such as "broken-link.jpg". In `Hero.tsx`, I will add the class `hero-image` to the `img` tag. This ensures that the broken image icon is never shown.

I've got it! The `img:not(.hero-image) { display: none !important; }` rule is the root cause. This CSS rule is hiding the `AboutUs.tsx` image (and all the others!), which is why the user isn't seeing it. I also know that the issue applies to all images lacking the `hero-image` class. payload.text: Las seccines deben tener una animacin de aparicin de primer mundo, super fluida, la primera seccin tambin

**Defining the Goals**

I'm currently focused on defining the core goals. It's about rebuilding and enhancing the application with world-class, smooth animations throughout, particularly the hero section. I've broken down the request into goals and current state analysis, and am now diving into the specifics of the current state.


**Analyzing the Implementation**

I've examined the provided codebase, which is React with Tailwind CSS. I've noted the lack of scroll entry animations, aside from a few basic keyframes in `index.html`. My focus now shifts to devising a lightweight animation strategy using `IntersectionObserver`, keeping in mind the need for "super smooth" animations, and aiming to avoid introducing new dependencies unless absolutely necessary. A custom hook and Tailwind transitions seem like a suitable path to a world-class feel.


**Devising the Animation**

I'm now designing the animation system. I'm focusing on a "premium" feel with a standard "Fade Up" animation, slightly sliding elements up and fading them in. I will also be looking at staggering element appearance within a section. I want to trigger animations when 10-20% of the element is visible, and use CSS transitions. I've designed `Reveal` as a component that handles the `IntersectionObserver`, initially setting `opacity-0 translate-y-8`, changing to `opacity-100 translate-y-0` when in view.



**Refining the Approach**

I'm now refining the animation strategy to ensure a more premium feel, aiming for granular animations within each section (`AboutUs`, `Services`, etc.). Instead of animating the entire section at once, I'm opting for individual animations for internal elements  title first, then text, then images. This detailed approach best aligns with the "detailed reconstruction" request. The global styles will be updated if needed, but Tailwind's arbitrary values work great. I'm building a new `Reveal` component that utilizes an `IntersectionObserver` to manage dynamic classes.


**Implementing the Reveals**

I'm now fully immersed in the implementation. I'm building out the `components/Reveal.tsx` component, ensuring it's reusable across all sections, as planned. The focus is on the `IntersectionObserver` logic within this component. I'm working with props for `children`, `className`, `delay`, `direction`, and `duration`, aiming for granular control. I'm avoiding any new dependencies, per the request, and will proceed with vanilla Javascript/React. I'm now applying a staggered approach to several components: the `Hero` (title and fade-up for the container), `WorkProcess`, `VisualGallery` and `Services` sections.


**Refining the Reveal System**

I'm now integrating the `Reveal` component into specific sections for granular animations. For the `Hero` section, I'm adding a fade-in to the background and bottom buttons. In `WorkProcess`, I'm mapping through steps with index-based delays. The `AboutUs` section will feature fade-in from the left for text and fade-in from the right for images. I also intend to stagger the appearance of cards in `Services`. I'm committed to meticulously reconstructing the animations as requested. I realized it may be tedious to update every file, but the granularity is crucial. I'll modify `App.tsx` and the individual components to use this refined system.


**Consolidating the Logic**

I'm now bundling the `IntersectionObserver` logic. I decided to build a standalone `Reveal.tsx` component to handle the observer, making it easier to integrate throughout the application, rather than a custom hook or utility. I'll focus on the sections and the first section as an optimization to prevent issues with the XML output or potential timeouts. The component needs to manage the `ref` and `isVisible` state, and have a default style of `transform: translateY(30px); opacity: 0; transition: all 0.3s ease;` for the initial state.


**Integrating the Components**

I'm now integrating the updated `Reveal` component across the application. I'm focusing on the `Hero`, `WorkProcess`, `AboutUs`, `VisualGallery`, `Services`, `WhyChooseUs`, and `ConsultationForm` components, as per plan. I've added a custom easing curve. The initial states include `transform: translateY(30px); opacity: 0; transition: all 0.3s ease;`, changing to the final state: `transform: translateY(0); opacity: 1;`. I have completed implementation.


**Refactoring the Reveals**

I'm now refactoring the reveals. Rather than modifying several files, I'm wrapping the contents of the target components within the `Reveal` component to reduce the number of files to modify. I also plan to add the base styles within `index.html` to ensure global and hardware-accelerated "smoothness." I will then update `App.tsx`, `Hero.tsx`, `WorkProcess.tsx`, `AboutUs.tsx`, `Services.tsx`, `WhyChooseUs.tsx`, `VisualGallery.tsx`, `ConsultationForm.tsx`, and `Footer.tsx`.


**Enhancing the Component**

I'm currently updating `Reveal.tsx` to handle flex layouts seamlessly with a default `width: '100%'`. I've added the initial state and is now refactoring the `Hero` section to trigger animations on mount with `triggerOnce` and possibly `delay`. Now the project is ready to execute!

Para lograr esa animacin de "primer mundo" (world-class), fluida y profesional, implementar una estrategia basada en **Intersection Observer**.

Esto permitir que los elementos no solo "aparezcan", sino que se deslicen suavemente a su posicin con una curva de aceleracin elegante (cubic-bezier) a medida que el usuario hace scroll.

Aqu estn los cambios detallados:

1.  **Nuevo Componente `Reveal.tsx`**: Este ser el motor de las animaciones. Envolver cualquier contenido y manejar la lgica de aparicin.
2.  **Actualizacin de todas las secciones**: Se integrar `Reveal` en cada componente, aadiendo retrasos escalonados (staggering) para que los elementos (ttulos, tarjetas, textos) aparezcan en secuencia y no todos de golpe.
3.  **Hero Section**: Tendr una animacin de carga inicial inmediata, sin esperar al scroll.

Se aplican animaciones escalonadas (staggered) a los pasos del proceso.
Animaciones independientes para la imagen y el texto (efecto parallax suave).

Agrega logo en la ltima seccin:https://i.imgur.com/Ai2rvKO.png.

**Defining the Goals**

I've zeroed in on the core objectives: integrating a specified logo into the footer section. It's becoming clearer where the focus should be  pinpointing the final section to place the image and determining if any resizing is required.


**Addressing the Desktop Issue**

I'm now zeroing in on the video display on the desktop, where it's currently appearing cropped. The mobile view is ideal, so I need to preserve that. I'm focusing on the `VisualGallery` component and its video container styles. The problem is the `object-cover` style, which isn't scaling effectively across devices. The constraint means a lot, as preserving the mobile view is essential.


**Pinpointing Code Locations**

I've determined the exact location for the logo integration. It's within the `Reveal` block of `components/Footer.tsx`, specifically the "Lnea Final y Copyright" section. For the video aspect ratio, I've confirmed that the mobile view is preferred; it's `h-[60vh]` with `object-cover`. On the desktop, the problem's in `md:h-[80vh]` with `object-cover`, leading to cropping on wider screens. I'm weighing solutions using `object-contain`. I have a better feel for the issue.


**Analyzing the Display Issue**

I'm now diving deeper into the nuances of `object-cover` versus `object-contain`. I'm leaning toward the user's need, where the video is getting "cortado." If it's a decorative background, `object-cover` is okay. However, this looks like a product video, so `object-contain` or adjusting the aspect ratio seems wiser. Considering the video's URL, it's probably a vertical social media video, explaining the desktop cropping with `object-cover`.


**Refining the Approach**

I'm now contemplating refining the desktop display of the video, weighing the merits of `object-contain` versus `object-cover`, while thinking of blur background options or letterboxing. My thought is `object-contain` might yield excessive empty space. The hybrid approach, centering the video with a max width constraint, may be worth exploring. I'm focusing on user need, which is content visibility, and believe `object-contain` on MD screens is the safest bet.


**Implementing the Display**

I've decided to implement `md:object-contain` (or perhaps `md:w-auto md:mx-auto`) to display the entire video on the PC. I'll also add a `bg-[#051130]` to the container to ensure the background matches the theme. My goal is to use the simplest robust fix. The container is wide, and the video is vertical, so this meets the objective.


**Updating the Implementations**

I'm now implementing the identified changes. In `components/Footer.tsx`, I'll replace the text with the specified image, ensuring correct sizing, perhaps with `h-12` or `w-auto`. For the video in `components/VisualGallery.tsx`, the goal is to fully address the cropping on desktop. The `<video>` class will be updated from `w-full h-full object-cover` to `w-full h-full object-cover md:object-contain`, along with a background color for the container.


**Integrating the Logo**

I'm now integrating the logo, swapping out the "FAN INDUSTRIAL" text in `components/Footer.tsx` with the provided image. I've used `h-10 w-auto` for sizing. The goal is to cleanly replace the text, assuming the logo includes the name, or to keep them side by side if the logo is icon only.

Aqu tienes los cambios solicitados.

1.  **En `components/Footer.tsx`**: Se ha reemplazado el texto "FAN INDUSTRIAL" por la imagen del logo proporcionada (`https://i.imgur.com/Ai2rvKO.png`) en la seccin final del pie de pgina.
2.  **En `components/VisualGallery.tsx`**: Se ajust el comportamiento del video. En mviles se mantiene `object-cover` (rellena toda la pantalla), pero en PC (pantallas medianas en adelante `md:`) se cambia a `object-contain`. Esto asegura que el video se vea completo sin cortarse, rellenando el espacio sobrante con el color de fondo institucional para mantener la elegancia.

payload.text: No me gust en PC el video, en mvil esta excelente asi. Pero en PC creo que es mejor ponerlo a un lado en forma vertical y no en el centro, y las imgenes a la par como son 4 2 arriba y 2 abajo

**Refining Desktop Design**

I'm currently focused on redesigning `VisualGallery.tsx` for desktop layouts. The existing structure features a full-width video followed by an image grid, which needs refinement. I'm exploring layout options to enhance the user experience on larger screens, considering both visual appeal and efficient content display. The core goal is to maintain the hierarchical arrangement of the video and the image content, and to have the desktop layout reflect the mobile design (which has a 2x2 grid) when expanded to a 1x4 image grid.


**Revising PC Layout**

I'm now revising the desktop layout to include a vertical video on one side and a 2x2 image grid on the other. This ensures the video isn't centered, as requested. The core component, `VisualGallery.tsx`, is being adapted to support this two-column grid structure on desktop, while maintaining the existing mobile-first design.


**Implementing Full-Width Video**

I've implemented the full-width video display at the top using the provided video URL. I've also incorporated a black overlay with the `z-10` index, so it doesn't interfere with the immersive viewing experience, and is pointer events none. I'm focusing on ensuring it auto-plays, loops, and is muted. The section's `h-[60vh] md:h-[80vh]` ensures the height adapts across different screen sizes.


**Defining Grid Dimensions**

I'm now defining the grid dimensions for both mobile and desktop views. The goal is to ensure the video height aligns with the image grid's height on larger screens. I'm structuring a grid container that morphs between a flex column on mobile and a two-column grid on desktop, for better display. I'm focusing on calculating a consistent height for the video to match the 2x2 square image grid on the right, providing a vertical form.


**Structuring Video and Images**

I'm now structuring the desktop layout with a grid for a vertical video on the left, which should use `object-cover` to fit, and a 2x2 image grid on the right, as requested, to have a more visually balanced look. The overall container will be a `grid md:grid-cols-2`, with the video taking up 50% of the space. payload.text:
Este boton: MS DETALLES SOBRE NUESTRO TRABAJO, lo dirige al formulario.

Y la pgina se tambalea al deslizar, solo eso.  

Bueno adems al correr el cdigo en vercel se pone en Blanco, arregla esto, no es un error en el diseo sino en la plataforma de vercel

**Refining the Redirect**

Okay, I've got it. My primary focus is understanding the user's initial request. It's about fixing that "MS DETALLES SOBRE NUESTRO TRABAJO" button in `WorkProcess.tsx`. The goal is to make it link to the contact form section (#consultation) instead of the mailto link. I am working on the appropriate adjustments now.


**Analyzing the Instability**

I'm now investigating the page "wobble" issue, suspecting horizontal overflow is the root cause. My next steps involve scrutinizing elements for excessive widths, and ensuring `overflow-x: hidden` is correctly implemented across the body, HTML, and main containers. Simultaneously, I've hit a white screen error on the Vercel deployment and have hypotheses, like a missing script tag. I'm exploring the directory structure, the React root, and if the entry point is correctly linked in HTML.


**Diagnosing the Missing Script**

I've got a critical piece: the `index.html` is missing the crucial script tag to load the application. It looks like the deployment is expecting a build step, like Vite or CRA, which is standard. Since there is none, I think the user is assuming an in-browser transformer. I need to figure out which setup is intended  Babel or some other approach  to compile the JSX on the fly. I'm leaning toward checking how the user expects it to run, which likely informs how the entry point is handled!


**Confirming the Build Process**

I've got it. The `index.html` is missing the crucial script tag for the application to load, which points to the entry point `index.tsx`. I'll add `<script type="module" src="./index.tsx"></script>` to `index.html`. Since the import map uses `esm.sh` and the deploy is Vercel, it appears there's an assumption of a build tool such as Vite, but I need to make sure!


**Pinpointing the Culprit**

I'm now zeroing in on the "wobble" issue, and it's looking like it stems from `overflow-x` problems. I've noted that `index.html` has `overflow-x: hidden`, but several components have widths or transforms that could cause horizontal overflow. Specifically, I suspect `WhyChooseUs.tsx`, `AboutUs.tsx`, and `VisualGallery.tsx` might be contributing due to their use of `absolute`, `transform`, or `w-full` inside a `grid`. The `Navbar` and `TopBar` *look* fine, but the scrollbar fluctuation is likely a contributor.


**Reinforcing the Overflow**

I'm now implementing the overflow fix. My latest findings show that explicitly setting `overflow-x: hidden; width: 100%; position: relative;` on the `body` is crucial, in addition to the `html` tag. I'm also examining the `ContactCTA.tsx` and its negative margin, which might be a contributor. I will make sure the parent `main` in `App.tsx` correctly handles overflow, and that `body` also handles overflow. The user pointed out the wobbling happens when sliding/scrolling, so it looks like it is an issue with the width that needs to be clarified.


**Implementing the Button Link**

I've updated the `WorkProcess.tsx` button's `href` to point to `#consultation`. I've also added the crucial script tag to `index.html`. Furthermore, I've applied the necessary CSS to `index.html`, explicitly setting `overflow-x: hidden; width: 100%;`. I am now making sure that the main wrapper div in `App.tsx` has the relevant classNames. I am confident in these modifications.


**Clarifying the Build Process**

I'm now zeroing in on the compilation process. My recent analysis points to a browser-native module setup using an import map, specifically `esm.sh`. This strongly suggests the need for a JSX transformer like Babel Standalone, since I see the typical `import React from 'react'` syntax that requires compilation. However, I need to check the code! I see no trace of Babel. The user may need a build step, even with `esm.sh`. I will see what other clues I can find.


**Confirming the Overflow**

My focus is the "Tambalea" (wobble) and I'm ensuring all horizontal overflow issues are addressed. I'm verifying that the `overflow-x: hidden` fix is applied across `html` and `body` in `index.html`. Furthermore, I've checked `App.tsx` and am adding the `overflow-x-hidden` class to its main wrapper div to reinforce the fix. I've updated the button and the script! I'm now certain the horizontal "Tambalea" is due to `translateX`!

Aqu tienes las correcciones solicitadas:

1.  **Botn en "Cmo Trabajamos":** He actualizado el enlace para que dirija al formulario de consulta (`#consultation`) en lugar de abrir el correo.
2.  **Pantalla Blanca en Vercel:** El error principal era que el archivo `index.html` no estaba "llamando" a tu archivo de cdigo `index.tsx`. He agregado la etiqueta `<script>` necesaria para que la aplicacin arranque.
3.  **"Tambaleo" (Wobble):** He reforzado los estilos globales para asegurar que no haya desbordamiento horizontal (`overflow-x: hidden`) ni en el `body` ni en el contenedor principal de la App, lo que evita que la pgina se mueva hacia los lados al hacer scroll.

Se agrega el script module apuntando a index.tsx para solucionar la pantalla blanca en Vercel y se fuerza overflow-x hidden en body para evitar el tambaleo.
Se aade overflow-x-hidden al contenedor principal para reforzar la prevencin del tambaleo lateral.

payload.text: El boton enviar consulta se sale del borde, centralo

**Inspecting the Problem**

I'm currently focused on the `ConsultationForm` visual bug, specifically the "Enviar consulta" button's misbehavior. It's exiting its designated border and needs to be properly centered. My analysis began with a close examination of the component's structure and CSS, trying to understand where the layout breaks. I'm moving toward identifying the root cause of the positioning issue.


**Analyzing the Code**

I've been looking closely at the `ConsultationForm.tsx` code, and I see the button's inside a `div` with `pt-4`. This `div` defaults to block display, so the `w-full md:w-auto` on the button gives it full width on small screens and auto width on desktops, defaulting to left alignment. The user wants the button centered. I think I need to add `flex justify-center` or `text-center` to the container to achieve this.


**Implementing the Solution**

I've decided to modify the code. I'm adding `flex justify-center` to the submit button's container `div`, changing `<div className="pt-4">` to `<div className="pt-8 flex justify-center">`, addressing both the requested centering and some additional padding for visual balance. I'll need to check the mobile behavior if the button content overflows the border. My focus will be on the button styling and how the text flows, especially on smaller screens. I will also check that the correct file, `components/ConsultationForm.tsx`, is my target for the update.


**Refining the Approach**

I'm now diving deeper into the specific implementation details, after I added `flex justify-center` to the submit button's container `div`, changing `<div className="pt-8 flex justify-center">`. I've also taken into account the existing `w-full` on the button, and my concern about text wrapping if necessary. The current `text-xs` font size should help with text overflow, though I'll be watching the right side for any visual issues. I have the new XML ready.


**Revisiting the Strategy**

I'm now zeroing in on the user's specific complaint: the "Enviar consulta" button is visually overflowing its container. I'm considering various scenarios, like a potential height issue, but I'm leaning towards the interaction of `w-full` on smaller screens and the parent's padding or fixed width on larger screens. While `w-full` should typically respect parent padding, I wonder if the particular combination of tracking and padding creates overflow. The fix I'm testing involves making the container `w-full`, and I'll revisit the buttons' class names to be more precise, including `w-full md:w-auto`. Ensuring the parent is a flex container with `justify-center` will be key to centering the button, especially on larger screens.


**Confirming the Approach**

I'm solidifying my approach: the core fix will remain `flex justify-center` on the container `div`. After the previous tests, I am ready to stick with the established strategy: keeping `w-full` on mobile for better touch targets. Now, I have verified the target file and the correct changes. I am ready to move forward.

payload.text: Haz las letras pequeas de toda la pgina que se vean, por aquello de personas que les cueste ver, deben verse bien, no claras ni blancas, deben visualmente leerse correctamente, solo eso lo dems de la pgina djala tal y como est

**Considering Text Readability**

I'm focusing on improving small text visibility throughout the application. My primary concern is addressing potential readability issues for users who struggle with tiny or light-colored text. The aim is to ensure all elements are easily legible, no matter the user. I'm exploring different solutions to apply this.


**Analyzing Text Elements**

I've identified several areas needing adjustments to improve text legibility across the application. I've pinpointed specific components, including `TopBar.tsx`, `Navbar.tsx`, `Hero.tsx`, `WorkProcess.tsx`, `AboutUs.tsx`, `WhyChooseUs.tsx`, `Services.tsx`, `Footer.tsx`, and `ConsultationForm.tsx`. I've documented all instances of small font sizes and low-contrast color choices. My action plan includes increasing font sizes below 12px to 13px or 14px, and increasing contrast.


**Adjusting Text Visibility**

I'm now implementing the color and size adjustments I planned. I'm focusing on increasing contrast, changing opacity levels (e.g., `text-white/40` to `/70` or `/80`), and bumping up font sizes. Smaller fonts (10px, 11px) are being increased to `xs` (12px), `sm` (14px). I've also swapped lighter grays (`300`, `400`, `500`) for darker shades for better readability. I'm maintaining the existing layout and color scheme.

Para mejorar la legibilidad y accesibilidad de la pgina sin alterar su diseo y esttica premium, he realizado los siguientes ajustes tcnicos:

1.  **Incremento de Tamao**: Se han subido los tamaos mnimos de fuente. Lo que estaba en `9px`, `10px` u `11px` se ha ajustado a un rango de `12px` a `14px` (equivalentes a `text-xs` y `text-sm` de Tailwind).
2.  **Optimizacin de Contraste**: Se han reemplazado colores como `text-gray-400` o `text-white/40` (que pueden ser difciles de leer) por grises ms oscuros (`text-gray-600`) o blancos ms opacos (`text-white/70`), asegurando que resalten sobre sus respectivos fondos.
3.  **Peso Visual**: Se ha mantenido la tipografa pero asegurando que los textos informativos tengan un grosor adecuado para no "perderse" visualmente.

Somos una empresa orgullosamente costarricense que cuenta con 12 aos de experiencia proporcionando soluciones a nuestros clientes.

Motivados en la excelencia y el compromiso, nos esforzamos por ofrecer servicios y productos de alta eficiencia y fiabilidad, superando las expectativas de nuestros clientes a travs de una atencin personalizada y un enfoque en la innovacin. Nuestro Objetivo

Dnde estamos

Excelencia Garantizada
); }; export default AboutUs;

payload.text: Las imgenes de la web sin animacin

**Analyzing Animation Implementation**

I'm currently focused on how animations are implemented for images on the website. I've found that animations are primarily managed through a `Reveal` component. This component utilizes `IntersectionObserver` to trigger transitions and reveal elements, which I intend to scrutinize in more depth.


**Disabling Image Animations**

I'm now zeroing in on removing image animations. The initial approach seems to be modifying the `Reveal` component, potentially with a `direction="none"` prop or a global disable switch. I'll need to examine `Services.tsx`, `GreaseExtractionSection.tsx`, `AboutUs.tsx`, `VisualGallery.tsx`, `WhyChooseUs.tsx`, and `Hero.tsx` to find where the `Reveal` component is used for images. The aim is to eliminate the fade-in and slide-in effects for images only, though other effects might need review too.


**Refining Animation Removal Strategy**

I'm now implementing the "senior frontend engineer" approach. Instead of a blanket disable, I'm focusing on selectively removing image animations. I've examined `AboutUs.tsx`, `VisualGallery.tsx`, `Services.tsx`, `GreaseExtractionSection.tsx`, `WhyChooseUs.tsx`, and `Hero.tsx`. I need to remove `Reveal` components around the images in each, also with `duration={0}` and `direction="none"` when necessary. I am also removing and adjusting effects like `group-hover:scale-110`, `animate-bounce-slow`, etc. This looks like the most targeted way to get the requested result.


**Implementing Animation Removal**

I'm now zeroing in on removing image entrance animations. My updated strategy involves modifying the components directly. I've started by removing the `Reveal` component from `AboutUs.tsx` and `VisualGallery.tsx` images and am also removing the corresponding hover effects. My next steps are to tackle `Services.tsx`, `GreaseExtractionSection.tsx`, and `WhyChooseUs.tsx`, which seems to be the most targeted approach.


**Refining Animation Transitions**

I'm now refining the strategy. Instead of a general removal, I'm focusing on removing animations from images, but keeping them for text elements. I'm swapping out `Reveal` components with `div` wrappers for images in `AboutUs.tsx` and `VisualGallery.tsx`. Next, I'll tackle the `GreaseExtractionSection.tsx` images and other sections, making targeted replacements. The goal is to specifically eliminate image animations.

payload.text: Las imgenes de los abanicos ms grandes

**Adding New Product Details**

Okay, I'm working on incorporating the new "Abanicos industriales de pared y Piso" product into the `Services.tsx` component. I'm focusing on the image placement right now, and ensuring the provided images render properly. I'm considering best practices to maintain a clean and responsive design for different screen sizes. I also need to make sure the presentation of images is in line with the established standards, and that all metadata is provided.


**Considering Image Size Adjustments**

I'm thinking about making the "Abanicos industriales" images larger within the `Services.tsx` component. The `ProductBox` uses a fixed `aspect-square`, so I'm exploring options. I can adjust the grid for that specific item, use a different aspect ratio within `ProductBox`, or even use a different layout. Setting `imagePadding="p-0"` in the `ProductBox` might also make the images appear larger, which is worth testing. I'm leaning towards grid adjustments to maintain consistency.


**Adjusting Grid Layout Options**

I'm now focusing on making the "Abanicos" product card more visually prominent in the desktop view. I've realized simply adding it to the existing grid might not be sufficient. I'm exploring expanding the card to span two columns using `lg:col-span-2`. This should provide more space for the images. Alternatively, I can adjust the aspect ratio of the image container within `ProductBox` using a prop, but grid adjustments feel more consistent. The current grid setup presents 5 axial products in total.


**Refining Image Display Strategy**

I'm now implementing the `aspectRatio` prop for the `ProductBox` component to provide more layout flexibility. I will be able to apply changes like `aspect-[16/9]` on the "Abanicos" product. I'm considering using `lg:col-span-2` on the grid and tweaking the aspect ratio to maintain a balanced look. Testing the visual impact of the `lg:col-span-3` layout revealed it's too large, so I'm focusing on the smaller span.


**Finalizing Display Configuration**

I've determined that `lg:col-span-2` for the "Abanicos" product works perfectly within the existing grid. To optimize image display, I'll be implementing the `aspect` prop in the `ProductBox` component to enable a custom aspect ratio. With `lg:col-span-2`, the card and image now will fit in one row. I'm going to set it to an aspect ratio of `aspect-[16/9]` and set `imagePadding="p-0"` to maximize the image's prominence, and I think it will be the final step for this feature.

**Addressing Image Cropping**

I'm currently focused on the "Filtro Sinttico" product box within the `Services.tsx` component. The user flagged an issue with a recently added image, specifically `https://i.imgur.com/JliRGGe.png`, as being cropped. I'm investigating how to best adjust the image display to resolve this.


**Analyzing Image Display**

I've determined the "Filtro Sinttico" product box is suffering from an `object-fit: cover` issue, explicitly set with `imageFit="cover"`. I'll remove this property to revert to the default `object-fit: contain`, ensuring the entire image displays, which is the user's main concern. The `imagePadding="p-0"` setting also contributes, and I'll revisit it if the uncropped image touches the edges awkwardly, although that isn't the primary goal here. I suspect the "Ductera & Rejillas" row's aspect ratio might also be a factor, so I'll review how that influences the image.


**Refining Image Display**

I've decided to replace `imageFit="cover"` with `imageFit="contain"` within the `ProductBox` component for the "Filtro Sinttico" product. The goal is to ensure the entire image is visible, directly addressing the user's reported cropping issue. I've also spotted how the `ProductBox` component dynamically handles image arrays, which will come in handy if I need to adjust it to show multiple images better. I'll test it out and maybe fine-tune the padding.

payload.text: Al entrar a la web, las imgenes cargan la mitad y otras nada

**Analyzing Image Load Times**

I'm currently investigating a performance issue where images are loading incompletely on the website. I see that many high-resolution images, sourced from Imgur, are used. Specifically, `VisualGallery.tsx` is loading 12 images, which seems excessive given the performance problem. I'm focusing on these images as a likely bottleneck.


**Refining Optimization Strategy**

I'm now expanding the performance analysis beyond `VisualGallery.tsx`. I see that `Services.tsx` also loads a considerable number of images, which might be contributing to the incomplete loads. The user's description "cargan la mitad" seems like a network or size issue, but also possibly linked to the `Reveal` component's timing. I'm focusing on lazy loading, adding placeholder elements, and controlling the image "complete" state to resolve the partial renders.


**Improving Image UX**

I'm now implementing strategies to improve image loading and the user experience. I'm focusing on `VisualGallery.tsx`, `Services.tsx`, and `GreaseExtractionSection.tsx`. To fix the "half-loading" effect, I'm wrapping images in colored containers and using opacity transitions triggered by the `onLoad` event. I'll also address the potential `IntersectionObserver` issue within the `Reveal` component and create a `SafeImage` or apply the `onLoad` pattern consistently. I suspect the issue might relate to large image sizes from Imgur.

Para solucionar el problema de carga parcial de las imgenes ("carga a la mitad"), he implementado una tcnica de **fading y placeholders** en todos los componentes. 

### Especificaciones de la optimizacin:

1.  **Estado de Carga (onLoad)**: Ahora las imgenes permanecen ocultas (con `opacity: 0`) hasta que el navegador confirma que se han descargado por completo. Una vez listas, realizan un **fundido suave (fade-in)** de 500ms.
2.  **Placeholders Estticos**: Mientras la imagen descarga, el usuario ver un fondo de color slido con un efecto de pulso sutil. Esto evita la sensacin de "vaco" o de "pgina rota".
3.  **Lazy Loading Nativo**: Se ha reforzado el atributo `loading="lazy"` en todas las imgenes que no estn en el primer pantallazo (Above the fold), priorizando el ancho de banda para lo que el usuario ve primero.
4.  **Prevencin de Layout Shift**: Todos los contenedores de imgenes ahora tienen relaciones de aspecto (aspect-ratio) definidas para que el diseo no "salte" mientras las fotos cargan.

Y pega esto dentro:<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">

Debe estar en la raz del proyecto (no en una carpeta).

**Generating Sitemap**

I'm working on generating the `sitemap.xml` file. The content is ready, and I'm currently figuring out the best way to place it in the root directory alongside `index.tsx`, `metadata.json`, `index.html`, and `App`. I'm considering different methods to automate this placement for easier updates.

entries.description: Se cre el archivo sitemap.xml en la raz del proyecto para mejorar el rastreo e indexacin por parte de los motores de bsqueda.

diffs.replacement:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<urlset xmlns="http://www.sitemaps.org/schemas/sitemap/0.9">
  <url>
    <loc>https://extractores-industriales-fan-cr-ca.vercel.app/</loc>
    <lastmod>2026-02-10</lastmod>
    <changefreq>weekly</changefreq>
    <priority>1.0</priority>
  </url>
</urlset>
